An element $e \in M$ is called a unit element or a neutral element with respect to the law of composition on $M$ if $ea = a = ae$ holds for all $a \in M$. Such a unit element $e$ is uniquely determined by its defining property; it is usually denoted as 1.
Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A left coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $aH = \{ah; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.
For a ring R, the set of multiplicatively invertible elements is denoted by R*. These elements are called the units of R.

Let $R$ and $R'$ be rings. A map $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a ring homomorphism if it satisfies two conditions: (i) $\varphi(a+b)=\varphi(a)+\varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$, making $\varphi$ a group homomorphism with respect to addition, and (ii) $\varphi(a \cdot b)=\varphi(a) \cdot \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$ and $\varphi(1)=1$, making $\varphi$ a monoid homomorphism with respect to multiplication.
A proper ideal $\mathfrak{p} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a prime ideal if for elements $a, b \in R$, $ab \in \mathfrak{p}$ implies $a \in \mathfrak{p}$ or $b \in \mathfrak{p}$.

For an integral domain $R$, the field of fractions $Q(R)$ is the set of equivalence classes of pairs $(a, b)$ where $a, b \in R$ and $b \neq 0$, under the equivalence relation defined by $(a, b) \sim (a', b')$ if and only if $ab' = a'b$.
An element x of an A-module M is called a torsion element if there exists an element a in A-{0} such that a.x = 0.
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is integral if every element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ in the way described in the definition of an integral element over a ring.

An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).

A group $G$ is called solvable if there exists a chain of subgroups $G_{0} \\supsetneq G_{1} \\supsetneq \\ldots \\supsetneq G_{r}=\\{1\\}$ such that each $G_{i+1}$ is a normal subgroup of $G_{i}$ and the residue class group $G_{i} / G_{i+1}$ is abelian.
The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A ring homomorphism is a generalization of an integral ring homomorphism. An integral ring homomorphism is a specific type of ring homomorphism where every element of the codomain is integral over the domain, thus inheriting all properties of a ring homomorphism and adding additional conditions.
